review.title: Identifying Bengali Multiword Expressions using Semantic Clustering
review.abstract: One of the key issues in both natural language understanding and generation is the appropriate processing of Multiword Expressions (MWEs). MWEs pose a huge problem to the precise language processing due to their idiosyncratic nature and diversity in lexical, syntactical and semantic properties. The semantics of a MWE cannot be expressed after combining the semantics of its constituents. Therefore, the formalism of semantic clustering is often viewed as an instrument for extracting MWEs especially for resource constraint languages like Bengali. The present semantic clustering approach contributes to locate clusters of the synonymous noun tokens present in the document. These clusters in turn help measure the similarity between the constituent words of a potentially candidate phrase using a vector space model and judge the suitability of this phrase to be a MWE. In this experiment, we apply the semantic clustering approach for noun-noun bigram MWEs, though it can be extended to any types of MWEs. In parallel, the well known statistical models, namely Point-wise Mutual Information (PMI), Log Likelihood Ratio (LLR), Significance function are also employed to extract MWEs from the Bengali corpus. The comparative evaluation shows that the semantic clustering approach outperforms all other competing statistical models. As a by-product of this experiment, we have started developing a standard lexicon in Bengali that serves as a productive Bengali linguistic thesaurus.
histories: 25 pages, 3 figures, 5 tables, International Journal of Linguistics and Language Resources (Lingvistic{\ae} Investigationes), 2014
review.COMMENTS: 25 pages, 3 figures, 5 tables, International Journal of Linguistics and Language Resources (Lingvistic{\ae} Investigationes), 2014

metadata.title: Identifying Bengali Multiword Expressions using Semantic Clustering

sections.text: The semantics of an MWE cannot be expressed after the semantics of its components have been combined. Therefore, the formalism of semantic clustering is often seen as a tool for extracting MWEs, especially for languages with limited resources such as Bengali. The current semantic cluster approach helps to localize clusters of the synonymous noun present in the document. These clusters, in turn, help to measure the similarity between the constituent words of a potentially aspiring phrase using a vector space model and assess whether this phrase is suitable as an MWE. In this experiment, we apply the semantic cluster approach to nounnoun bigram MWEs, although it can be extended to all kinds of MWEs. Parallel, the known statistical models show that we also apply these semantic cluster approaches to other competing MWEs.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: Over the past two decades, Multiword Expression (MWEs) has emerged as a kind of isolated case that is being pursued with increasing interest in the field of computer-based linguistics and natural language processing (NLP) (Rayson, 2010, p. 1). The term "MWE" is used to refer to various types of linguistic units and expressions, including phrases (many words of thanks), etc. However, while there is no universally agreed definition of MWE, most researchers use the term to refer to these common phrases that are subject to a certain level of semantic optics. Sag et al al al. (2002, p. 1) define them as "idiosyncratic interpretations."

sections.heading: 1. Multiword Expressions (MWEs)
sections.text: It is difficult to say which characteristics a person carries in himself and which he does not carry in himself. It is not that he carries in himself. It is not that he carries in himself. It is not that he carries in himself. It is not that he carries in himself. It is as if he goes in himself. It is as if he has turned into himself. It is as if he has turned into himself. It is as if he has turned into himself. It is as if he has turned into himself. It is as if he has turned into himself. It is as if he has turned into himself. It is as if he has turned into himself. It is as if he has drawn into himself. It is as if he has drawn into himself. It is as if he has drawn into himself. It is as if he has drawn into himself.

sections.heading: 3. Semi-automated Approach for Candidate Extraction
sections.text: This year it is so far that it will only take one year to move on to the next round.

sections.heading: 4. Baseline System
sections.text: As already mentioned, the task of identifying Bengali nouns from a document is little attention in the literature, and therefore there is no previously developed methodology that can be used for the baseline. Therefore, in this experiment, we are simply able to adapt a heuristics to develop our baseline system. Phrases that do not have nominal indicators and determinants at the prefix and suffix positions are selected as MWEs in the baseline system. Of course, the baseline system achieves a high accuracy in relation to most of the identified MWEs meet the above-mentioned candidates, but in terms of precision it shows a very low accuracy (38.68%), as many collocalized and fully compositional elements were incorrectly identified as MWEs. The main challenge of our model was to filter these irrelevant collocations from the selected candidate.

sections.text: In fact, it is such that most of them will be able to move into another world, in which they are able to move, in which they move, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they, in which they, in which they live, in which they, in which they live, in which they, in which they live, in which they, in which they, in which they live.

sections.heading: Algorithm:MWE_CHECKING
sections.text: Input: Noun-noun bigram < M1 M2 > Output: Return true if MWE, or return false. 1. Extract semantic clusters of M1 and M2 (discussed in Section 6.4); 2. Intersect the clusters of M1 and M2 (Figure 3 (left) shows the common synset entries (broken rectangles) of M1 and M2); 3. For measuring the semantic similarity between M1 and M2: 3.1. In an n-dimensional vector space (n) are the number of elementscommon in the synsets of M1 and M2, e.g. in the Figure 3 (left), n = 2, the common entries act as the axes. Put M1 and M2 astwo vectors and their associated similarity with the axes tokens as their co-ordinates.3.Calculate cosine similarity measurement measurement measurement measurement measurement and dependance two distectors.

sections.heading: 7. WordNet::Similarity Measurement
sections.text: We also include English WordNet 2.17 in this experiment to measure the semantic distance between two Bengali words after we have translated them into English. Although the idea is trivial when considering the manual intervention of the translation process, our main focus was to get an idea of how the semantic similarity of two components can help identify the combination as MWE, and how a well-defined lexical tool is indispensable in the currently adapted linguistic environment. As mentioned above, WordNet:: Similarity is an open source package developed at the University of Minnesota to calculate the lexical similarity between word (or sense). Basically, it offers six measures of similarity and three measures of kinship based on the lexical WordNet database (Fellbaum, 1998).

sections.heading: 9. Discussion
sections.text: At the beginning of the article, we argued that the increasing degree of semantic similarity between two components of a candidate bigram indicates that the candidate is less likely to be a multi-word expression. Statistical methods achieve low accuracy because the medium-sized corpus does not provide significant evidence of its occurrence to designate the non-compositional expression as MWEs. We have taken an approach that takes into account the semantic interpretation of MWEs, which seems to be unconventional when it comes to identifying MWEs in any language. In the experimental results, the semantic cluster approach outperforms the other systems, but the cluster algorithm is able to identify those MWEs whose semantics are completely opaque to the semantics of their components (strictly non-compositional).

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: We have introduced a semi-automatic approach to establish the hypothesis. We have compared our results with the base system and traditional statistical systems. We have shown that clustering measures can be an effective measure to improve the extraction task of MWEs. Contributions in the paper are four-fold: firstly, we offer an efficient method for clustering noun signs with similar meaning; secondly, we propose a semantic, similarity-based approach to the identification of MWEs; thirdly, it is a preliminary attempt to reconstruct a monolingual Bengali dictionary as a standard lexical thesaurus; and finally, the current task is a groundbreaking step towards the development of Bengal WordNet. Finally, we would like to stress that this entire methodology can be used to identify MWEs in any other linguistic domain.

metadata.abstractText: One of the key issues in both natural language understanding and generation is the appropriate processing of Multiword Expressions (MWEs). MWEs pose a huge problem to the precise language processing due to their idiosyncratic nature and diversity in lexical, syntactical and semantic properties. The semantics of a MWE cannot be expressed after combining the semantics of its constituents. Therefore, the formalism of semantic clustering is often viewed as an instrument for extracting MWEs especially for resource constraint languages like Bengali. The present semantic clustering approach contributes to locate clusters of the synonymous noun tokens present in the document. These clusters in turn help measure the similarity between the constituent words of a potentially candidate phrase using a vector space model and judge the suitability of this phrase to be a MWE. In this experiment, we apply the semantic clustering approach for nounnoun bigram MWEs, though it can be extended to any types of MWEs. In parallel, the well known statistical models, namely Point-wise Mutual Information (PMI), Log Likelihood Ratio (LLR), Significance function are also employed to extract MWEs from the Bengali corpus. The comparative evaluation shows that the 372 Chakraborty et al. semantic clustering approach outperforms all other competing statistical models. As a byproduct of this experiment, we have started developing a standard lexicon in Bengali that serves as a productive Bengali linguistic thesaurus.
